p: The need to engage communities is recognised as essential for an effective response. Several articles reported fear and mistrust of international responses as a challenge for research delivery [ 18, 51, 69, 71, 79]. Integrating all stakeholders into each step of the developing research programme [ 3, 48, 69], engaging communities as partners [ 1, 3] and gaining an understanding of power dynamics [ 34] were facilitators cited to address this. It was also emphasised that interventions need to be culturally sensitive [ 27, 29, 44, 50, 51, 58] and respond to national as well as global need [ 36]. Examples of community engagement included regular information sessions [ 3, 5, 16, 29, 34, 42, 69â€“ 71], joint communication plans [ 20, 29], outreach health promotion teams [ 69] and formation of community advisory boards [ 69].
